replication_study.hypothesis: At the U.S. county level, a higher 2016 Donald-Trump vote share (measured in percentage-point differences) will be associated with a decrease in social-distancing behaviour, operationalised as the percentage-point change in the share of resident devices that stay completely at home during 19 Mar – 01 Apr 2020 relative to 16 – 29 Feb 2020.

data_plan.source_type: Aggregated anonymised mobile-device location data merged with county-level socio-economic and election data
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Mobility: 16–29 Feb 2020 (reference) and 19 Mar–01 Apr 2020 (analysis window). County covariates are time-invariant 2014–2018 ACS averages; 2016 MIT Election vote shares.
data_plan.sample_size: ≈3 000 counties after merging and list-wise deletion (exact N printed by script at runtime).
data_plan.access_details: CSV files already provided in /app/data/original/1/python/replication_data (no further permissions required).

qualification.explanation: The new file `transportation.csv` provides an independently collected mobility measure that captures stay-at-home behaviour — conceptually identical to the social-distancing construct in the original study, yet derived from a different mobility provider. Merging with `county_variables.csv` recreates the full set of socio-economic and political covariates.
qualification.similarity_to_original: Both studies use anonymised mobile-device data to quantify county-level social distancing and merge them with MIT Election Lab 2016 vote shares (post_registration.json → data.source) as well as ACS socio-demographics (post_registration.json → data.source). The same focal independent variable (2016 Trump vote share) and very similar outcome (reduction in mobility vs increase in stay-at-home share) are available in the replication dataset (see columns `trump_share`, `pop_home`, `pop_not_home` in county_variables.csv and transportation.csv).
qualification.deviation_from_original: The replication’s mobility comes from the Transportation Statistics file (transportation.csv) rather than Unacast (post_registration.json → data.source) and uses device-level ‘stay-home’ counts instead of average distance travelled. The time window differs (replication: 19 Mar–1 Apr; original: 19–28 Mar). Therefore the replication constitutes an independent test.

data_plan.notes: Variable names differ slightly (e.g., `percent_male` vs `male_percent`) and have been harmonised in the Python script. Percentages are stored in 0–100 format except for a few 0–1 proportions that are rescaled in code.

steps: Load county-level covariates (county_variables.csv) and daily mobility data (transportation.csv).
Create a time-period flag (reference, March-analysis window) and compute the proportion of devices staying completely at home for every county-day.
Aggregate to county × period means, pivot to a wide format, and calculate the percentage-point change from reference to March (prop_home_change_march).
Merge with county covariates and rescale variables (e.g., income expressed in $1 000, percentages scaled to 0–100).
Estimate an ordinary-least-squares regression of prop_home_change_march on Trump vote share plus covariates, including state fixed effects via dummy variables.
Obtain robust (HC1) standard errors, compute the effect of a one-inter-quartile-range (IQR) increase in Trump share, and test it with a two-sided t-test.
Save regression output and summary statistics to /app/data/replication_results.csv.
planned_method.models: OLS with state fixed effects (dummy-variable approach) and robust (HC1) SEs.
planned_method.outcome_variable: prop_home_change_march – percentage-point change in stay-at-home share (March vs reference).
planned_method.control_variables: income_per_capita (thousands USD), male_percent, percent_black, percent_hispanic, percent_college, percent_retail, percent_transportation, percent_hes (health/education/social-services employment), prop_rural; plus state dummies.

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient for trump_share and the derived IQR-scaled effect.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: t-test (two-sided) on coefficient and on IQR-scaled effect; robust HC1 variance.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion of rows with missing outcome, trump_share, or state.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Reject H0 if p < 0.05 and coefficient is positive (less stay-at-home = decrease in social distancing). Directionality must match the original negative association (i.e., IQR effect should be < 0).

files.replic_analysis.py: Main entry-point. Loads data, constructs variables, runs OLS with state fixed effects, computes IQR effect, prints and saves results to /app/data/replication_results.csv.

codebase.notes: The script is a Python rewrite of the relevant sections of kavanagh_analysis.R. All file paths reference /app/data to comply with execution guidelines.

analysis.instructions: From the project root, run `python /app/data/original/1/python/replication_data/replic_analysis.py`. The script prints the regression table and writes replication_results.csv into /app/data for comparison.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare the sign, magnitude (percentage-point change per IQR), and p-value of the Trump-share effect to the original study’s estimate (original: −4.1 pp, p < 0.001; post_registration.json → results.numerical_results[1]). Consistency in negative direction and statistical significance supports replication.
